statement.tex: \text{Find the second order derivative of the }\\ \text{function } x^3 \, \log x.

step.context: \text{Is the following the correct way to }\\ \text{find } \dfrac{d^2{f(x)}}{dx^2}\text{ where $f(x) = x^3 \log x$}?
step.tex: \text{First, finding the first order derivative}\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d(f(x))}{dx} &= \dfrac{d(x^3 \log x }{dx}\\ &= \dfrac{d(x^3)}{dx}. \log x + x^3 . \dfrac{d(\log x)}{dx}\\ &= 3x^2 . \log x + x^3 . \dfrac{1}{x}\\ &= 3x^2 . \log x + x^2 \end{align}\\ \text{Now, finding the second order derivative}\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d^2(f (x))}{dx^2} &= \dfrac{d(f^{\prime}(x))}{dx}= \dfrac{d(3x^2 . \log x + x^2)}{dx}\\ &= \dfrac{d(3x^2)}{dx} . \log x + 3x^2 . \dfrac{d{(\log x)}}{dx} + \dfrac{d(x^2)}{dx}\\ &= 6 x . \log x + 3 x + 2x\\ &= x(5 + 6 \log x)\\ \end{align}
